questions.stem: Weber's theory of bureaucracy describes an ideal organizational structure characterized by:

options.text: Flexible, ad hoc decision-making based on personal relationships
Clear hierarchy, formal rules, division of labor, and impersonal relationships based on technical competence
Complete worker autonomy with no supervisory oversight
Decision-making by consensus among all organizational members

questions.explanation: Weber's (1922) bureaucratic model describes an 'ideal type' (theoretical construct, not necessarily ideal in a normative sense) characterized by: clear hierarchy of authority, formal rules and procedures, division of labor and specialization, impersonal relationships (decisions based on rules, not personal favoritism), selection and promotion based on technical competence, and written documentation. Weber saw bureaucracy as the most rational and efficient form of organization. Critics (Merton, Gouldner) later identified dysfunctions: trained incapacity, goal displacement, and rigid adherence to rules that undermines organizational goals.

questions.stem: McGregor's Theory X and Theory Y represent contrasting assumptions about human nature. Theory Y assumes that:

options.text: Workers are inherently lazy and must be controlled and threatened to perform
Workers are naturally motivated, can exercise self-direction, and seek responsibility under the right conditions
Workers are motivated solely by financial incentives
Workers cannot be trusted to make any decisions

questions.explanation: McGregor (1960) proposed that managerial behavior is driven by assumptions about human nature. Theory X assumes workers are lazy, dislike work, avoid responsibility, and must be coerced and controlled. Theory Y assumes work is as natural as play, workers can be self-directed and creative, seek responsibility, and are motivated by higher-order needs when organizational conditions allow. McGregor argued that Theory X creates a self-fulfilling prophecy—controlling management produces passive, dependent workers. Theory Y management, by contrast, creates conditions for self-actualization. This connects to Maslow's hierarchy and Argyris's maturity theory.

questions.stem: Mintzberg's structural configurations identify five basic organizational forms. Which configuration is characterized by standardization of work processes, a large technostructure, and centralized decision-making?

options.text: Simple structure
Machine bureaucracy
Professional bureaucracy
Adhocracy

questions.explanation: Mintzberg's (1979) machine bureaucracy relies on standardization of work processes as its primary coordinating mechanism, with a large technostructure (analysts who design systems for standardizing work), centralized decision-making, and formalized rules. Examples include mass-production factories and large government agencies. Simple structure relies on direct supervision. Professional bureaucracy standardizes skills (hospitals, universities). Divisional form standardizes outputs. Adhocracy uses mutual adjustment and is suited to innovation and complex, dynamic environments.

questions.stem: Lawrence and Lorsch's contingency theory of organization proposes that organizational effectiveness depends on achieving a balance between:

options.text: Theory X and Theory Y management styles
Differentiation (specialization to match environmental demands) and integration (coordination among differentiated units)
Centralization and decentralization of all decisions equally
Formal and informal communication channels

questions.explanation: Lawrence and Lorsch (1967) found that organizations in complex, dynamic environments need to simultaneously differentiate (create specialized subunits that match their specific subenvironments) and integrate (coordinate these differentiated units toward common goals). The key insight is that more differentiation requires more sophisticated integration mechanisms. Organizations facing stable environments can use simpler structures, while those in dynamic environments need more differentiation and more complex integration. This was one of the first contingency approaches to organizational design.

questions.stem: Katz and Kahn's open systems theory views organizations as:

options.text: Closed systems that operate independently of their environment
Open systems that import energy/resources from the environment, transform them, and export outputs
Machines that can be perfectly designed and controlled
Collections of isolated individuals with no interdependence

questions.explanation: Katz and Kahn (1966) applied general systems theory (von Bertalanffy) to organizations, describing them as open systems with key properties: importation of energy (raw materials, human resources, information from the environment), throughput (transformation of inputs through work processes), output (products, services exported to the environment), cycles of events (recurring patterns), negative entropy (organizations must import more energy than they expend to survive), feedback (information about outputs used to adjust processes), equifinality (multiple paths to the same outcome), and differentiation (tendency toward specialization).

questions.stem: The Hawthorne studies (Roethlisberger & Dickson) are significant in organizational theory because they revealed which findings? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Social and psychological factors significantly influence worker productivity
Informal group norms can be more powerful than formal incentives in determining output
Worker attention and participation in research can itself affect performance (Hawthorne effect)
Physical working conditions are the only determinant of productivity
The importance of understanding human relations in the workplace

questions.explanation: The Hawthorne studies (1924-1932) at Western Electric's Hawthorne plant produced several groundbreaking findings: social/psychological factors affect productivity beyond physical conditions (A); informal work group norms powerfully regulate output—workers restricted production to avoid rate-busting or chiseling (B); the Hawthorne effect—being studied itself affected behavior (C); and the studies launched the Human Relations movement, emphasizing social needs, group dynamics, and participative management (E). They contradicted the scientific management assumption that physical conditions are the sole productivity determinant (D is incorrect).

questions.stem: Taylor's principles of scientific management include which of the following? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Scientific study of each task to determine the 'one best way'
Scientific selection and training of workers
Cooperation between management and workers based on scientific principles
Worker autonomy to determine their own methods
Division of work responsibility between management (planning) and workers (execution)

questions.explanation: Taylor's (1911) four principles of scientific management: (1) Scientifically study each task to find the optimal method (A); (2) Scientifically select and train workers for each job (B); (3) Ensure cooperation between management and workers through incentive systems (C); (4) Divide work so management handles planning and workers handle execution (E). Worker autonomy in methods (D) is contrary to scientific management—Taylor advocated that management, not workers, should determine the best methods. Critics argued this approach dehumanized work and created adversarial labor relations, but it did increase efficiency and laid groundwork for industrial engineering.

questions.stem: According to organizational ecology (Hannan & Freeman), which of the following are key concepts? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Structural inertia—organizations have difficulty changing fundamental structures
Environmental selection—the environment selects organizations that fit, similar to natural selection
Population-level analysis—studying birth and death rates of organizational forms
Organizations can always easily adapt to environmental changes
Legitimacy and competition affect organizational founding and failure rates

questions.explanation: Organizational ecology (Hannan & Freeman, 1977) applies evolutionary theory to organizations: Structural inertia limits organizations' ability to change (A)—internal and external pressures maintain existing structures. Environmental selection operates on populations of organizations (B)—environments 'select' organizations that fit. The analysis unit is populations of organizations (C)—studying founding rates, failure rates, and the life cycles of organizational forms. Legitimacy and competition affect founding (density dependence) (E). Organizations cannot always adapt (D is incorrect)—ecology argues that adaptation is often too slow, and selection (organizational failure) is the primary mechanism of change.

questions.stem: Institutional theory proposes that organizations adopt similar structures and practices due to which of the following pressures? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: Coercive isomorphism—pressure from regulations, laws, and powerful organizations
Mimetic isomorphism—imitating successful or prominent organizations under uncertainty
Normative isomorphism—professionalization and shared training producing similar practices
Pure efficiency—organizations adopt practices solely because they are the most productive
The pursuit of legitimacy in the institutional environment

questions.explanation: DiMaggio and Powell's (1983) institutional theory identifies three mechanisms of institutional isomorphism (organizational homogeneity): Coercive—pressure from regulations, laws, and dominant organizations (A); Mimetic—copying other organizations under uncertainty (B); Normative—professional norms and shared training producing similar practices (C). A key insight is that organizations adopt practices for legitimacy (E), not just efficiency. Organizations may adopt structures that are symbolically appropriate even if they don't improve performance ('ceremonial adoption'). Pure efficiency (D) is the rational explanation that institutional theory challenges.

questions.stem: Weick's concept of organizational sensemaking includes which of the following propositions? (Select ALL that apply)

options.text: People in organizations actively construct meaning from ambiguous situations
Sensemaking is retrospective—people make sense of events after they occur
Enactment—people create the environments they then respond to
Organizations have fixed, objective realities that are universally perceived the same way
Identity shapes what people notice and how they interpret events

questions.explanation: Weick's (1995) sensemaking framework: Organizations are not fixed realities but are actively constructed through meaning-making (A). Sensemaking is retrospective—people create interpretations of what happened after the fact (B). Enactment is crucial—people don't just respond to environments; they partly create them through their actions and interpretations (C). Identity is central—who people believe they are shapes what they notice and how they interpret events (E). There is no fixed objective reality universally perceived the same way (D is incorrect)—different organizational members may construct very different understandings of the same events.

questions.stem: Match each organizational theory to its primary theoretical perspective:

columns.text: Classical/rational—one best way to organize work for efficiency
Humanistic—social needs and group dynamics drive productivity
Contingency—optimal structure depends on environmental demands
Systems—organizations are complex entities exchanging with environments

questions.explanation: Scientific management (Taylor) represents the classical/rational perspective—efficiency through task analysis and standardization. Human Relations (from Hawthorne studies) represents the humanistic perspective—social factors and group dynamics matter. Lawrence and Lorsch's contingency theory argues there is no one best way—optimal structure depends on environmental demands. Katz and Kahn's open systems theory views organizations as complex adaptive systems in constant exchange with their environment. This progression reflects organizational theory's increasing appreciation for complexity and context.

questions.stem: Match each Mintzberg structural configuration to its primary coordinating mechanism:

columns.text: Direct supervision by the strategic apex
Standardization of work processes by the technostructure
Standardization of skills through training and professionalization

questions.explanation: Mintzberg's five configurations each rely on a different coordinating mechanism: Simple structure (entrepreneurial firms)—direct supervision by the owner/leader. Machine bureaucracy (mass production, government)—standardization of work processes designed by analysts. Professional bureaucracy (hospitals, universities)—standardization of skills achieved through professional training. Adhocracy (consulting firms, R&D labs)—mutual adjustment, informal communication suited for innovation in complex, dynamic environments. The fifth, divisional form, relies on standardization of outputs.

questions.stem: For each organizational theory era, select ALL key contributions it made:

columns.text: Attention to social needs and group dynamics
Recognition that there is no 'one best way'—context matters
Understanding organizations as open systems exchanging with environment

questions.explanation: Classical era (Taylor, Weber, Fayol): Contributed task analysis, work standardization, and time-and-motion studies—focusing on efficiency and rational organization. Human Relations era (Mayo, McGregor, Argyris): Shifted attention to social needs, group dynamics, and the importance of participative management. Systems/Contingency era (Katz & Kahn, Lawrence & Lorsch, Burns & Stalker): Recognized that optimal organization depends on context (no universal best way) and that organizations are open systems in dynamic exchange with environments. Each era built on and reacted against the limitations of the previous one.

questions.stem: For each organizational structure type, select ALL environmental conditions under which it is most effective:

columns.text: Need for both functional expertise and project coordination
Complex tasks requiring innovation and adaptation

questions.explanation: Burns and Stalker (1961) found: Mechanistic structures (clear hierarchy, formal rules, centralized decisions) fit stable environments with routine tasks. Organic structures (flexible, decentralized, horizontal communication) fit dynamic environments requiring innovation. Matrix structures (dual reporting—functional and project/product) are effective when organizations need both deep functional expertise and cross-functional project coordination, but create role conflict and ambiguity due to dual authority. This contingency perspective was foundational—structure should match environmental demands.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about classical organizational theory:

Taylor's scientific management sought the [BLANK1] for each work task through systematic study. Fayol identified [BLANK2] principles of management, including unity of command, scalar chain, and division of work. Weber described bureaucracy as based on [BLANK3] authority rather than traditional or charismatic authority. A common criticism of classical theories is that they treat workers as interchangeable parts of a [BLANK4]. The Human Relations movement, sparked by the [BLANK5] studies, challenged these assumptions by demonstrating the importance of social factors.
questions.explanation: Taylor sought the 'one best way' through time-and-motion studies. Fayol (1916) identified fourteen principles of management (unity of command, scalar chain, division of work, authority, discipline, etc.). Weber's bureaucracy rests on rational-legal authority—power legitimated by rules and procedures, not personal charisma or tradition. Critics called classical theory the 'machine model' because it treated organizations as machines and workers as interchangeable parts. The Hawthorne studies (1924-1932) launched the Human Relations movement by revealing the power of social factors.

questions.stem:
Complete the passage about open systems theory:

Katz and Kahn viewed organizations as [BLANK1] that import resources from the environment, transform them, and export products. A key property of open systems is [BLANK2]—the idea that the same end state can be reached through multiple pathways. Organizations must combat [BLANK3]—the natural tendency toward disorder and decline—by importing more energy than they expend. The [BLANK4] concept describes recurrent cycles of activity that give organizations stability. Open systems theory contributed to the development of [BLANK5] approaches that match organizational structure to environmental demands.
questions.explanation: Open systems theory (Katz & Kahn, 1966): Organizations are open systems in constant exchange with environments. Equifinality means multiple paths can reach the same outcome—there's no single best way to organize. Entropy (second law of thermodynamics) is the tendency toward disorder; organizations must import more energy (negative entropy) to survive. Cycles of events create stability through recurring patterns. Open systems thinking directly influenced contingency theory—if organizations interact with different environments, their structures must vary accordingly.

questions.stem: A hospital is organized as a professional bureaucracy (Mintzberg). Physicians have extensive autonomy in clinical decisions, but the administration is trying to implement standardized treatment protocols to reduce variation and costs. Physicians resist, arguing that clinical judgment should override standardized procedures.
questions.centerQuestion: What structural tension does this scenario illustrate?

options.text: Professional bureaucracies coordinate through standardization of skills, not work processes
Professionals derive authority from their expertise, not from organizational hierarchy
Standardized protocols threaten professional autonomy and discretion
Physicians have no understanding of organizational efficiency
Involve physicians in developing protocols (participative approach)
Use evidence-based guidelines that respect clinical judgment for exceptions
Simply impose protocols through hierarchical authority
Align protocols with professional values (patient outcomes, quality)

centerOptions.text: Tension between professional autonomy (skill standardization) and administrative standardization (process standardization)
The hospital needs to become an adhocracy

questions.explanation: This illustrates a fundamental tension in professional bureaucracies (Mintzberg): the operating core (professionals) is coordinated through skill standardization (training and professional norms), while administration seeks process standardization (protocols). Professionals derive authority from expertise, not hierarchy, creating natural resistance to administrative control of their work. Resolution requires respecting the professional bureaucracy's structure: involving professionals in protocol development, using evidence-based guidelines that preserve discretion for complex cases, and framing protocols in terms of professional values (quality, patient outcomes) rather than pure administrative efficiency.

questions.stem: A small technology startup has grown from 15 to 150 employees in two years. The founder still makes all major decisions personally, communication is informal and ad hoc, and there are no written procedures. Employees are frustrated by unclear roles and inconsistent decisions.
questions.centerQuestion: What organizational theory concept best explains this situation?

options.text: Simple structure has become inadequate for the organization's size
Direct supervision by one person cannot scale to 150 employees
Lack of formal role definitions creates ambiguity and conflict
The organization has too much bureaucracy
Introduce formal role definitions and reporting relationships
Delegate authority and create middle management layers
Develop standardized procedures for recurring decisions
Maintain the current informal structure to preserve startup culture

centerOptions.text: Structural crisis—the organization has outgrown its simple structure and needs formalization
The founder is an ineffective leader
The company should downsize back to 15 employees
The organization has too many formal rules

questions.explanation: This scenario illustrates Greiner's (1972) growth model and Mintzberg's structural theory. The startup began as a simple structure (appropriate for small size)—centralized authority, minimal formalization, direct supervision. As it grew, this structure became inadequate (Greiner's 'crisis of leadership'). The organization needs to transition toward more formalization: defined roles, middle management, standardized procedures. This doesn't mean becoming a rigid bureaucracy—it means developing structure appropriate to size. Maintaining pure informality at 150 employees leads to chaos, not creativity.

questions.stem: An organizational behavior student is reviewing foundational theories. Highlight the THREE accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Weber's bureaucracy is based on rational-legal authority, with rules and procedures governing behavior. (B) The Hawthorne studies confirmed that physical working conditions are the only factor affecting productivity. (C) McGregor's Theory Y assumes that people are inherently motivated and can exercise self-direction. (D) Burns and Stalker found that mechanistic structures are always superior to organic structures. (E) Argyris argued that formal organizations often create conditions that conflict with the needs of mature, healthy adults. (F) Fayol's principles of management were developed based on controlled laboratory experiments.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Weber's bureaucracy rests on rational-legal authority. (C) Theory Y assumes people are naturally motivated and capable of self-direction. (E) Argyris's maturity-immaturity theory argued that bureaucratic organizations keep adults in a state of dependency that conflicts with psychological maturity. Incorrect: (B) Hawthorne studies showed social factors matter—the opposite of this claim. (D) Burns and Stalker found that organic structures are better in dynamic environments—neither is always superior. (F) Fayol's principles were based on his experience as a mining executive, not laboratory experiments.

questions.stem: A management consultant is reviewing modern organizational theories. Highlight the FOUR accurate statements:
questions.passage: (A) Institutional theory (DiMaggio & Powell) explains organizational homogeneity through coercive, mimetic, and normative isomorphism. (B) Resource dependence theory (Pfeffer & Salancik) argues that organizations must manage their dependence on external resources. (C) Organizational ecology (Hannan & Freeman) emphasizes that organizations can always easily adapt to environmental changes. (D) Transaction cost economics (Williamson) explains organizational boundaries based on the costs of market versus hierarchical governance. (E) Weick's sensemaking framework emphasizes that people actively construct organizational reality through retrospective interpretation. (F) Complexity theory suggests that organizations should be understood as complex adaptive systems operating at the edge of chaos. (G) All modern theories agree that bureaucracy is the most effective organizational form.
questions.explanation: Accurate: (A) Institutional theory's three isomorphism mechanisms explain why organizations in the same field become similar. (B) Resource dependence theory focuses on managing environmental dependencies. (D) Transaction cost economics explains why organizations internalize some functions vs. contracting out. (E) Weick's sensemaking emphasizes active, retrospective construction of meaning. Incorrect: (C) Organizational ecology argues the opposite—structural inertia limits adaptation. (F) While partially accurate, the description is oversimplified. (G) Modern theories explicitly reject the idea of any single best organizational form.

questions.stem: Arrange the major eras of organizational theory in chronological order:

options.text: Human Relations era (Hawthorne studies, McGregor)
Classical/Scientific Management era (Taylor, Weber, Fayol)
Contemporary/Postmodern era (institutional theory, sensemaking, complexity)
Systems/Contingency era (open systems, Lawrence & Lorsch)
Neoclassical era (Simon's bounded rationality, behavioral decision theory)

questions.explanation: Organizational theory eras: (1) Classical (1900s-1930s)—Taylor's scientific management, Weber's bureaucracy, Fayol's administrative principles. (2) Human Relations (1930s-1950s)—Hawthorne studies, McGregor, Maslow. (3) Neoclassical (1940s-1960s)—Simon's bounded rationality challenged classical assumptions of perfect rationality. (4) Systems/Contingency (1960s-1980s)—open systems theory, contingency approaches matching structure to environment. (5) Contemporary (1980s-present)—institutional theory, organizational ecology, sensemaking, complexity theory, postmodern approaches. Each era responded to limitations of the previous one.

questions.stem: Arrange Greiner's stages of organizational growth in correct sequence:

options.text: Growth through delegation (crisis of control)
Growth through creativity (crisis of leadership)
Growth through collaboration (crisis of internal growth)
Growth through direction (crisis of autonomy)
Growth through coordination (crisis of red tape)

questions.explanation: Greiner's (1972) growth model: (1) Creativity—entrepreneurial growth until a leadership crisis (founder can't manage growing complexity). (2) Direction—professional management brings structure, until an autonomy crisis (lower levels feel stifled). (3) Delegation—authority is decentralized, until a control crisis (top management loses control). (4) Coordination—formal systems and procedures restore coordination, until a red tape crisis (bureaucracy becomes excessive). (5) Collaboration—teamwork and interpersonal solutions address rigidity. Each evolutionary period ends with a revolutionary crisis that requires a new management approach.

questions.stem: Review data on organizational survival rates under different environmental conditions and structural types:

datasets.name: Mechanistic orgs in stable environment - Survival %
Mechanistic orgs in dynamic environment - Survival %
Organic orgs in dynamic environment - Survival %

questions.question: What organizational theory do these data most directly support?

options.text: Scientific management—mechanistic is always best
Burns and Stalker's contingency theory—structure must match environmental demands
Human relations—social factors determine survival
Weber's bureaucracy—formal rules always ensure survival

questions.question: Why do mechanistic organizations have the lowest survival rate in dynamic environments?

options.text: Their rigid rules and centralized decision-making cannot adapt to rapid environmental changes
They have too many employees
They spend too much on research
Dynamic environments are actually easier for all organizations

questions.explanation: The data support Burns and Stalker's (1961) contingency theory: mechanistic structures (hierarchy, formal rules, centralization) survive well in stable environments where efficiency matters. In dynamic environments, their rigidity prevents adaptation, leading to high failure rates. Organic structures (flexibility, decentralized decisions, lateral communication) survive better in dynamic environments because they can adapt. This supports the contingency principle that effective organizational structure depends on environmental conditions—there is no universally best structure.

questions.stem: Examine data on organizational founding rates as a function of population density (institutional theory/organizational ecology):

questions.question: What explains the inverted-U pattern in founding rates?

options.text: Random variation with no theoretical explanation
Density dependence: at low density, increasing legitimacy encourages founding; at high density, competition discourages it
Government regulations that cap the number of organizations
Founding rates always increase with density

questions.question: What does the increasing failure rate at high density suggest?

options.text: High density creates intense competition for limited resources, increasing mortality
Organizations voluntarily shut down when they're successful
High density has no effect on organizational survival
Only the oldest organizations fail at high density

questions.explanation: These data illustrate organizational ecology's density dependence theory (Hannan & Carroll). At low density, each new organization of a type increases legitimacy, encouraging more founding—few competitors exist. As density increases, competition intensifies, discouraging founding and increasing failure. The founding rate follows an inverted-U: rising as legitimacy increases, then falling as competition dominates. Failure rates increase monotonically with density as competition for limited resources intensifies. This explains the life cycle of organizational populations—initial rapid growth followed by consolidation and shakeout.

questions.stem: Categorize each concept according to the organizational theory tradition it belongs to:

items.text: One best way to organize work (Taylor)
Equifinality—multiple paths to same outcome (Katz & Kahn)
Isomorphism—organizations becoming similar through institutional pressures

questions.explanation: Classical: Taylor's one best way and Weber's bureaucracy represent rational, universalistic approaches. Human Relations: McGregor's Theory X/Y and Hawthorne findings about informal groups and social needs. Systems/Contingency: Equifinality (open systems property) and differentiation-integration (contingency approach to structure). Contemporary: Institutional isomorphism (DiMaggio & Powell) and sensemaking (Weick) represent modern theoretical frameworks. The field has evolved from seeking universal principles to understanding organizational phenomena in context.

questions.stem: Categorize each organizational design element according to Mintzberg's framework of organizational parts:

categories.label: Middle Line (managers linking apex to core)

items.text: CEO and board of directors setting organizational strategy
Department heads translating strategy into operations
Quality control analysts developing inspection standards
Teachers delivering curriculum in a school
Training specialists designing employee development programs

questions.explanation: Mintzberg's five parts: Strategic apex—top management responsible for strategy and external relations. Operating core—workers performing the basic work of the organization (production workers, teachers, surgeons). Technostructure—analysts who standardize work through planning, training design, and quality control. Middle line—managers who connect the strategic apex to the operating core, translating strategy into operations. The fifth part, support staff (not included), provides indirect support (cafeteria, legal, PR). Different configurations emphasize different parts.
